App description:
The chaos moon is coming, threatening the peaceful inhabitants of the land. Its up to you to unlock the power of the gods in your battle against the encroaching darkness.

Become the hero in this first-person, legendary VR quest against the forces of evil.
Before completing this epic journey you will:

- Explore a wide and wondrous new world.
- Engage in ranged and melee combat with the sinister celestial servants of the chaos moon.
- Solve the mysteries of the ancients and gain the mystical power of the gods!

We are proud to support Cross-Buy - buy the game once and play it on Quest or Rift/Rift S!

For sensitive players or those new to VR, make sure to check out the pause menu movement options. You can walk around in that area and experiment to find the most comfortable configuration!

TURTLE ROCK STUDIOS, INC. PRIVACY POLICY

Effective May 18, 2017

INTRODUCTION

This Privacy Policy describes how Turtle Rock Studios, Inc. ("TRS," "we," "us" or "our") collects, uses, and shares information about you and applies to your use of any online service location that posts a link to this Privacy Policy and all features, content, and other services that we own, control and make available through such online service location (collectively, the "Services"). It also details the rights and choices you have regarding the use and disclosure of information about you collected through the Services.

By using the Services, you agree to our Terms of Use and consent to TRSs collection, use, storage, deletion, transfer to the United States, and disclosure of information relating to you as set forth in this Privacy Policy. For information on our compliance with the Privacy Shield Framework, please see "Privacy Shield and International Transfer" below. This Privacy Policy is effective as of the date set forth above and is only applicable to the Services and not to any other websites or online service locations that you may be able to access from the Services which may have their own data collection and use practices and policies.

TYPES OF INFORMATION WE COLLECT

Information You Provide

We and our Service Providers (defined below) may collect information you provide directly via the Services. For example, we collect information when you create an account on the Services; subscribe to our newsletter; participate in Services feedback, questionnaires, surveys, contests, sweepstakes, or other promotions; receive customer or technical support; play our games, or otherwise communicate or transact with us through the Services.

The information we collect may include personal information. "Personal information" means information that can be used to identify you personally (whether alone or in combination), such as your first and last name, email address, phone number, postal address, and payment card information.

If you do not disclose certain personal information to us, you may not be able to access certain aspects of the Services. For example, to create an account, we will require you to provide certain information, including your email address, user name, and password. If you sign up to the Services through a Third Party Service (defined below) such as Facebook, Twitter or Google Plus, we may also collect personal information during the sign-up process. For information on our relationship with social media platforms, please see "Social Media Features" below.

You may choose to voluntarily submit certain other information to us through the Services, including personal information, but you are solely responsible for your own personal information in instances where we have not requested that you submit such information to us.

Personal information once "de-identified" is not subject to this Privacy Policy and we and our Service Providers may treat it as non-personal information and use it without obligation to you except as prohibited by applicable law.

Information We Collect Automatically

In addition to any personal information or other information that you choose to submit to us via the Services, we and our Service Providers may use a variety of technologies that automatically store or collect certain information whenever you visit or interact with the Services ("Usage Information"). Usage Information may include IP address, device identifier, browser type, operating system, domain names, access times, and other information about your use of the Services. This Usage Information may be stored or accessed using a variety of technologies that may be downloaded to your personal computer, browser, laptop, tablet, mobile phone or other device (a "Device") whenever you visit or interact with the Services. To the extent we associate Usage Information with your personal information we collect directly from you on the Services, we will treat the combined information as personal information.

The methods that may be used on the Services to collect Usage Information include:

Log FilesLog files may record and store your Usage Information.

Information Collected by Tracking Technologies: Cookies, web beacons, tracking pixels, embedded scripts, location-identifying technologies, device fingerprinting, in-app tracking methods, and other tracking technologies now and hereafter developed ("Tracking Technologies") may be used to collect information about your interactions with the Services or emails, including information about your browsing and activity behavior.

Cookies

Cookies are small bits of electronic information that a website sends to a visitors browser and are stored on the visitors device. Like many websites, we employ cookies in certain areas of the Services to allow us to provide information to make your online experience more convenient and to enhance your experience with the Services. For example, when you return to the Services after logging in, cookies provide information so that the Services will remember who you are on subsequent visits, speeding up or enhancing your experience of the Services by, for instance, tailoring content to you. A user may configure his or her web browsers to accept or reject or delete the cookies, or notify the user when a cookie is being set, as further discussed in "Your Rights and Choices" below.

Web Beacons

We employ third party tracking utility software technology called web beacons or clear gifs, that help us better manage content on our Services by informing us what content is effective. Clear gifs are tiny graphics with a unique identifier, similar in function to cookies, and are used to track the online movements of users. In contrast to cookies, which are stored on a users device, clear gifs are embedded invisibly on web pages and are about the size of the period at the end of this sentence. In short, clear gifs enable two websites to share information with one another.

Tracking Pixel

A tracking "pixel" is a transparent graphic image (usually 1 pixel x 1 pixel) that is placed on a web page and allows for the collection of information regarding the use of the web page that contains the tracking pixel.

Location-identifying Technologies

GPS (global positioning systems) software, geo-filtering, and other location-aware technologies locate (sometimes precisely) you for purposes such as verifying your location and delivering or restricting relevant content based on your location.

Device Fingerprinting

Device fingerprinting is the process of analyzing and combining sets of information elements from your devices browser, such as JavaScript objects and installed fonts, in order to create a "fingerprint" of your device and uniquely identify your device and applications.

In-App Tracking Methods

There are a variety of tracking technologies that may be included in mobile apps and games, and these are not browser-based like cookies and cannot be controlled by browser settings. Some use device identifier, or other identifiers such as "Ad IDs" to associate app user activity to a particular app/game and to track user activity across apps/games.

Tracking Technologies Usage. We may use Tracking Technologies for a variety of purposes, including:

- Strictly Necessary. We may use Tracking Technologies that we consider are strictly necessary to allow you to use and access the Services, including cookies required to prevent fraudulent activity, improve security or allow you to make use of shopping cart functionality.

- Performance-Related. We may use Tracking Technologies that are useful in order to assess the performance of the Services, including as part of our analytic practices or otherwise to improve the content, products or services offered through the Services.

- Functionality-Related. We may use cookies or other tracking technologies that are required to offer you enhanced functionality when accessing the Services, including identifying you when you sign in to the Services or keeping track of our specified preferences, including in terms of the presentation of content on the Services.

Some information about your use of the Services and certain Third Party Services may be collected using Tracking Technologies across time and services and used by us and third parties for purposes such as to associate different devices you use, and deliver relevant ads and/or other content to you on the Services and certain Third Party Services.

For further information on Tracking Technologies and your choices regarding them, please see "Analytics and Advertising" and "Your Rights and Choices" below.

Information from Other Sources

We may obtain information about you from other sources, including Service Providers and Third Party Services, and combine such information with information we have collected about you. To the extent we combine such third party sourced information with personal information we have collected about you on the Services, we will treat the combined information as personal information under this Privacy Policy. We are not responsible for the accuracy of any information provided by third parties or third party policies or practices.

HOW WE USE YOUR PERSONAL INFORMATION

We may use your information, including personal information:

To manage our Services;
to process your registration with the Services, including verifying your information is active and valid, and to allow you to log in to the Services;
to send messages to you in response to your request to perform an activity in connection with your use of the Services, and to contact you regarding any customer or technical support issues;
to contact you with regard to your use of the Services and, in our discretion, changes to the Services and/or any of the Services policies, or when necessary;
to prevent and address fraud, breach of policies or terms, and threats or harm;
to monitor and analyse trends, usage, and activities;
to conduct research, including focus groups and surveys;
to improve the Services or create new service offerings, to customize your experience on the Services, or to serve you specific content that is relevant to you;
to send you commercial or marketing messages including, newsletters, promotions, updates, special offers, and email communications about our products or services (for information about how to manage these communications and marketing efforts, please see "Your Rights and Choices" below);
for internal business purposes; and
for purposes disclosed at the time you provide your information or as otherwise set forth in or as permitted by this Privacy Policy.

Use of Information for Recruitment Purposes: Where you have provided us with personal information as part of an online application for employment or internship, we may use that information in order to allow us to make an informed decision about whether to proceed with your application. We may, as part of this recruitment process, collect information about your education, employment history and similar matters. Where this personal information is considered to be sensitive, you expressly consent to our processing of this information for recruitment purposes by submitting it to us.

HOW WE SHARE YOUR PERSONAL INFORMATION

We may share the information about you, including personal information, under the following circumstances:

Service Providers. We may share your information with our agents, vendors, consultants, or other service providers ("Service Providers") that we engage for the purpose of fulfilling product orders, processing information on our and your behalf, operating or hosting the Services, or providing services related to the online components of our games. These Service Providers are prohibited from using your personal information other than to provide this assistance and are required to maintain appropriate confidentiality and security measures.

Partners. We may provide your information, including personal information, to our publishing partners and their affiliates in connection with the online components of our apps and games.

Protection of Rights. We must disclose your personal information in response to lawful requests by public authorities, including to meet national security or law enforcement requirements. We may also share your information, including personal information, if we have a good faith belief that (i) access, use, preservation or disclosure of such information is reasonably necessary to satisfy any applicable law, regulation, legal process, such as a court order or subpoena, or a request by law enforcement or governmental authorities, (ii) such action is necessary to detect, prevent, or otherwise address fraud, security or technical issues associated with the Services or violations of our Terms of Use, or (iii) such action is appropriate to protect the rights, property or safety of TRS, its employees, clients, or users of the Services or others.

Asset transfers. If we become involved in a merger, acquisition, bankruptcy or other transaction involving the sale of some or all of TRSs assets or a line of business, user information, including personal information collected from you through your use of the Services, could be included in the discussions and transferred assets. Should such an event occur, TRS will use reasonable means to notify you through a prominent notice on the Services after the deal is complete.

Internal Business Purposes. We may share your information, including personal information, with our affiliates for internal business purposes.

Direct Marketing Purposes. We may share your information, including personal information, with our affiliates, business partners, and other third parties for their own business purposes, including direct marketing purposes (for further information regarding your rights, see "Your California Privacy Rights" and "Your European Privacy Rights" below).

Consent and Pursuant to this Privacy Policy. We may share your information, including personal information, with third parties with your consent or for any purposes consistent with our statements under this Privacy Policy or as permitted by applicable law.

Without limiting the foregoing, in our sole discretion, we may share aggregated information which does not identify you or de-identified information about you with third parties or affiliates for any purpose.

SWEEPSTAKES, CONTESTS, PROMOTIONS

We may offer sweepstakes, contests, surveys, and other promotions (each, a "Promotion") jointly sponsored or offered by third parties that may require submitting personal information. PUBLIC INFORMATION

We are not responsible for the privacy or security of any information that you make publicly available on the Services or what others do with information you share with them on the Services. California residents have additional rights set forth in "Your California Privacy Rights" below.

CHILDREN'S PRIVACY

HutwolfJul 24 at 2:27 PM
Zelda on Quest? Not anywhere close.

The reviews hype this game up pretty high, so I admit, I did look forward to this - more than I should have. In the end, it's just kind of medicore and really, really short. The combat doesn't feel satisfying and the puzzle design barely has time to expand its ideas into anything noteworthy. Most mechanics blow over to fast, that they barely scratch the surface of what was possible with this game. There are a few cool parts, but again, blink and you miss it, it's not even worth mentioning.

It's also suprising how stiff and lifeless the world feels. The barest minimum of interactivity, no bashing enemies with the shield, no picking up random objects, no pulling levers, no climbing, just swing your sword and shoot your crossbow. The god powers don't make up for that, since they are mostly used for the few beginner level puzzles. The story is pretty simple too. Charming, I admit, but still not enough to make this an outstanding experience.

What is here, is still enjoyable, but overpriced and overpromised.

- The legend of Zelda has puzzles to solve, this doesnt.

Golden_MindJun 6 at 6:17 AM
Journey of discovery

Ok, interesting point of view from a YouTuber relating to finishing a game quickly, and it's not a quote direct but I'm referencing a view made.

They said that (the room vr: a dark matter) was shorter than expected but maybe it would be longer if they didn't use the tips available. Their fellow 'presenter' said that not following tips wouldn't make the game longer but it would take longer to finish the game.

I've noticed that YouTube gives away a lot of spoilers, or how to do it correctly, and this helps me personally to finish games quicker. Sometimes I wonder if spoilers ruin games but then I ask how far will I go again and again without progressing forward.

I needed YouTube to finish this game and although, without YouTube, I doubt I would have ever finished it... It didn't spoil it for me, I was relieved/happy to finish the game. Next time I play this game, it'll be easier and probably I will collect more stuff.

So yeah, it'll be nicer to replay the game and correct my own missed opportunities.

AxallApr 4 at 10:18 PM
A great, one time experience

This game has a ton of charm and enjoyed the experience throughout the whole game, but the lack of content and the catch when you beat the game left me feeling like I had been cheated (jump to "The Ugly" to see why)

The Good:
The art style and music are charming and give the game its unique style. Combat is smooth and simple. The abilities you gain throughout the game are unique and interesting, while only used in niche situations. The worlds you explore all have different themes and provide a decent amount of variety to the game. I found it challenging and engaging exploring each of these worlds for upgrades to my weapons and powers. And the last level is a great way to end the game, no spoilers for how it goes, but it was amazing and the feeling of conquering the last area gave me a feeling of accomplishment. The overall experience was very polished and complete. But...

The Bad:
Enemy types are lacking. While bosses are unique and engaging, the basic enemies you encounter feel repetitive after a while, and honestly fairly easy to beat (and I played this game on hard). I wish that enemies became harder or at least gained a few more mechanics throughout the game. The hub area you explore in between missions is WAY to big for what it offered. Looking back I can see why it was so big (no spoilers), but it was a pain visiting every place to get upgrades for my gear. The game is also fairly short, only 7 hours long

The Ugly:
You cannot replay previous levels. This is an EXTREMELY poor choice on the developer's side. This almost completely destroys the point of trying to find all the secrets in the levels. And when you beat the game, you CANNOT go back to play levels. If you try to play a game file you've beaten, all you get is the final cutscene. THAT'S IT. If you want to replay any levels or search the levels for secrets, you need to start a new game file. THIS is the reason why the game left such a bad taste in my mouth. The thrill of searching for secrets is gone.

phylum_sinterDec 13 at 6:08 PM
The Demo doesn't do it justice!

HOLY SHNIT, i completely undervalued how much fun this game is, how clever and simple it is at the same time, how gorgeous and vast it can be based on the demo alone.

Demo? Yeah if you haven't yet noticed, there is a Journey of the Gods demo... and it barely scratches the surface of the full experience. I wish it ended with a slideshow of the different levels and everything you can see, because the impression the demo left me with was a "how is this a $30 game?", thinking it would all be based around saving tiny people with my simple god grow-trees power, crossbow and sword.

The good news is that the demo doesn't show even 10% of what you'll see in the game. Some of the levels are much more detailed than that first farmyard in the demo, they have different mechanics, there's a boat ride at night and a level that is purely tower defense with magic powers -- and the god powers you get later in the game are so much more fun to use than the two you get in the demo.

I passed this game up almost solely on the demo and price of the full game, and i'm betting a lot of us did. But if you're at all aching for a "full game" experience, we may have to adjust our budget gauges. Yes, this game is more expensive than a good half of the stuff on the store -- but let me assure you that the budget of the game, the quality of the experience and for people like me who all too often equate game length with value, it wins that one too. I'm a good 5 hours into it, and the game tells me my save is at 33%.

The game has everything you'd expect from a full game - upgradeable weapons, exploration, a wide variety of levels with varied objectives, great art and sound. In conclusion -- if you've run away from this one because the demo didn't have you smiling from ear to ear, still try the full game, because it's the most complete Action Adventure game i've played on the Quest even this far into it, and every time i put it down i hope they make a sequel. Recommended!

Console quality

Journey of the Gods is a proper adventure game where you complete levels using a sword and shield along with a crossbow. You use your weapons to defeat many different enemy types through linear levels and solve the occasional puzzle. You are also given god powers that give you an aerial perspective of the area around you and those powers give you various abilities to solve puzzles and defeat enemies. -Visually pleasing
-Console like experience

Cons

BrostoyevskyFeb 26 at 12:26 PM
Regretful purchase

This review is coming from a person who never played Legend of Zelda before (which I see very often referenced in other views), with around ~5 hours of gameplay and 44% game completion.

I would've rated this game 5 stars as well if I would've written this review with just 2-3 hours of gameplay. However, not very far more into the game, you realise just what a poor decision has been to buy it.

You encounter very many issues with collision boxes (i.e. you hit something and it not registers) which is especially a massive issue when you're in God Mode and you want to strike something with lighting. What makes it worse is that regardless of whether the hit registers or not, your belief (i.e. mana) is still being charged an x amount for each lighting bolt. While this usually happens with lighting bolts, it does sometime happen with other attacks as well.

This would've been a little more bearable if you weren't stuck in an amazingly narrow way of how you should play this game and what you should do. "Have to teleport an old man out of a cage and the only intuitive place to do so is the literally large land a few meters from the cage? No, you absolutely can't do that for reasons, teleport him on the tree on which the cage is hanged."

Also, the atrocious interplay between the two issues mentioned above is that very many times you're put in an awkward position in which, for example, you have to destroy something with a lighting bolt, but the hit doesn't register and you assume you might need to do it in another way, but just after a while you realise you just have to spam lighting bolts until something connects since there's no other conceivable way to achieve the said objective.

There are nice things that can be said about the game, sure. There are many things which are done alright and which are nice. But at least for me, the issues which I talked about were simply too frustrating to enjoy the game. They really sucked all of the enjoyment from my experience.

King-Ry-RyJan 19 at 10:02 AM
Basically VR Zelda...ITS INCREDIBLE!!

Like most people I got really excited about this game When I saw the trailers. The price tag looked a bit steep in comparison to the rest currently in the store and so was a bit hesitant at first. Most games in the store dont usually give a very long experience and so I was uncertain this would deliver a game length worthy of its price tag. I went to check out the demo first. This gave me a good sense of the amazing mechanics of the game and the world it was set in. But the level seamed very short and gave me the impression that the full experience would be brief one. I left it alone for a few months and decided to go for it after reading some reviews explaining how the demo didnt do it justice.

Im so happy I decided to go for the full version as its easily one of the best games on the quest so far!! And that demo level was a fraction of what the level in the real game actually is! This game is basically Zelda in VR and its incredible! The mechanics are smooth and weapons feel great to use. Especially the crossbow! In the demo the God state felt a bit gimicky but in the full version it brings great variety and tactical choice to the puzzles and monsters you encounter in the game. The puzzles are again very Zelda like which is great! Never bog down the pace of the game and satisfying to complete. The monsters that you come up against are wonderfully varied and put up a good fight when theres a few of them. What I like most about them is the sound design! Some of the most incredible noises they make really add scale and atmosphere to a fight. The big walkers that tower over remind me of the walkers in half life 2 and sound so good! Well done to whoever was involved in that.

The level design is also very impressive and varied! And start to get really trippy towards the end levels. They are open enough to make you want to explore but are tight enough that you dont feel like your wasting your time exploring. The colour scheme and art style are perfect for the Quest. The colours are bold but not too bright so they dont become fatiguing on the eyes. They help give a comfortable experience to quite an action packed game. The art style is beautifully simple and full of character without feeling dumbed down. Its the kind of design thats perfect for the Quests limited processing power which I hope other developers go for in future games.

Theres not too much text reading when interacting with characters which is great as it lets you get on with the fun stuff! That said the story is light also, its enough to give flavour to the world and a sense of purpose In The game but doesnt dump heaps of info on you that you have to remember which Ive always found too much in other games.

And finally the length of the game is exactly what I was hoping for! A well fleshed out lengthy adventure thats well worth the asking price. Sure Id always want more levels, but as it is, it doesnt disappoint. The game is well polished and deserves more content for it in the future. More like this please! Lots more!

DEVELOPERS

Apart from the strange ending this game is amaze balls!! Please please make a Journey Of The Gods 2 with a good 60 hrs of gameplay!! Id happily pay 50 or 60 for an epically long sequel! Like our favourite classic adventure games we all used to play.

clintlandonJan 14 at 11:05 AM
Amazing, But Has a Comfort Flaw

I thoroughly enjoy this game in a way few VR games click with me. This game not only captures my attention, but also my imagination, and thats no small feat.

However, I can only play a level at a time before I get uncomfortable and have to stop. Since I just finished Boneworks, I cant say motion sickness is a problem for me anymore, but for some reason this game wears me down.

I think theres two reasons this game might make my head hurt. One is how the vignette opacity cant be raised to be more solid. I honestly dont think the vignette is much of a factor, but its unique and so is this problem for me, so 

The major problem is locking movement to your head. When a game is built to encourage looking around, having your movement tied to your perspective means youre kinda punished for taking in the sights without totally stopping movement. I get combat would cause their own movement issues with how you block and reload your crossbow, but I usually lock my defensive stance anyways, having gotten used to this kind of combat in Skyrim VR. I just wish I had the option to have movement locked to my hands so I could look around if thats what I wanted.

Overall, this is a truly great game. Its just hampered by limited comfort options.

I was skeptical about playing it. It is more or less Zelda for VR. The scope of the game is not huge and epic but its easy to pick up and plays well. Theres some great character and level design on display. Some great visual story telling. To me it reminds me a lot of old school platformers on the PS1 and 2. There are few bugs here and there but they're largely negligible and for the price I think its a great experience overall. Highly recommend playing it if you haven't done so yet. If I have one complaint is there is not a lot of replay value. I beat it a while back and I picked up once after to 100% it and it didnt take me very long. Its a short game but its a work of art and even if something I would pick up and play every day I think this will go down as a VR classic that really showed the scope of what could be accomplished on something like the Quest.

obi2kenobiAug 17, 2019 at 5:54 AM
This game is a reason to have VR

I am pretty discriminating when it comes to game prices. So generally I hesitate to buy a $30 game. In fact the only other $30 title I have is beatsaber. But the quality and fun factor here does not disappoint.

If you are a fan of a Zelda like action/adventure/fantasy games, this is a must-own title. Along with training to be a Jedi, becoming a sword wielding hero is another king among nerd fantasies. Isn't that why we love VR? To make our dreams come true?

Not that the game is about swordplay, at all. But it gives a great fantasy/magic feel with the visuals and unique God powers which to me are a great innovative use of VR perspective. The sense of scale is awesome too, the environments and enemies get huge.

This is miles beyond a generic hack and slash game. Very pleasing picturesque visuals and creative gameplay set this game apart from the rest. Oh and there are multiple save slots so you can share with friends and family :)

Update: now 44% of the way through. It is still awesome, but I have to complain about the lightning mechanic. I have had an extremely tough time getting it to work. And its required to advance through certain areas.

I will also comment that the coolest and most unique part of this game is the scale. Monsters and bosses look huge and fighting against things that appear 10-60ft tall is incredible. Plus there is this one monster that charges at you and it gets my heart racing. Great immersion! Just wish i had the space to walk around instead of relying on joystick movement. Would make it truly epic.

Tons of fun!

I was shocked when I first played this game, I seriously did not expect to enioy it as much as I have. The games is relatively simple, you get a sword, shield, and a crossbow at your disposal to take out your enemies. As well as an interesting god form that grants special abilities, such as smiting your enemies or growing trees. Your equipment is upgradable, using various equipment piece found throughout the game. You also unlock different god abilities as you progress through the story. The game is not an open world game as I had expected with more linear styled levels to traverse through. The corssbows reloading system is quite finicky, you are supposed to pull a lever to reload the bow, but many times it doesn't get pulled all the way. Its especially annoying when I'm surrounded and trying to reload quickly only for the bow not to reload, causing me to die. Other than that, its a quite pretty, and entertaining game that I enjoyed slicing and dicing my enemies to bits. Certainly a must have for the Quest.

GabeNewelIMay 25, 2019 at 2:18 PM
Enchanting and empowering

This game is the closest feeling you'll get to playing Zelda in VR today. The environments are simple but beautiful, the gameplay is smooth as silk with satisfying combat and God powers, the enemies are intimidating and interesting. The art style and animations make the NPCs super charming even if they're pretty simple polygons with no spoken dialog. The entire time I have spent playing I just keep thinking to myself that this is a really good foundation for a series.

While it's a great start all is not perfect. I can't help but feel like the level based design constrains the feeling of completeness of the world, and there's an overemphasis on combat over puzzles so far imo. The lack of written or spoken npc dialog is also a missed opportunity, because I think it could help make the world feel more fleshed out and lived in. The story is kind of ho hum as well, but servicable and lends itself well to the gameplay.

Overall I definitely recommend this game to anyone looking to catch some Zelda vibes in VR, and really hope it's not the last we see of this world. I think a sequel/expansion with more emphasis on adding story and puzzles could be fantastic.

BattleProgrammerJun 10, 2019 at 3:23 PM
Good game

The graphics aren't very detailed and don't look amazing on screenshots, but they work well enough while in the actual game. The mechanics are good -- a lot of variety both in the player's abilities and the enemies. The plot is a bit "meh", not bad, but nothing amazing either, but this is a game one plays for the gameplay and not the plot.

I only count two annoyances during the entire game:

1. There's one section where one needs to put weight on a beam to raise the player to the right place. This happens exactly once in the whole game, and isn't hinted at all that it's even possible. Given the rest of the game it seems a bit of an oversight as every other mechanic is well explained. This one comes out a bit out of the blue, and is only used once to boot.

2. Sometimes the game uses icons over characters' heads to tell the player what they want. This is sometimes confusing and obscure, and seems odd given how the game is perfectly able to give me a dialog with text. It doesn't happen a lot, but it's a bit weird and annoying -- a character that formerly could speak to me suddenly needs me to play a game of charades as if they had lost the ability to speak. There's one part where a bunch of characters stand in a circle and seem to want to shake hands. Turns out they want me to turn around and leave. That got me a bit confused for a bit.

Overall none of this is a big deal, and they're the only minor details I think could be improved.

It does involve a bit of experimentation on the players part at times, to figure out how to move on as the game doesn't really hold your hand while playing through it, so you are left scratching your head at times and wondering what you're supposed to do next or if you have missed something! It's not too hard to figure out usually but some bits do become a bit frustrating (I am stuck at the man in the cage over the lava at the moment! Can't figure out how to get him out for love nor money!). It's quite easy to lose a good few hours in VR with this game, which is always a good sign. I tend to use the 2hrs (give or take) battery time as a sign to have a break, but if you're the type who gets engrossed in the world of VR, then you'll probably need a good battery pack, because this game seems a decent size for a mobile VR game. I'm probably 4hrs in, and I don't think I'm even half way yet. The actual levels are broken up into stages though taking place in different areas, so it's also perfect for a fairly quick (20/40min) blast of a level or two at a time. Although the art style is quite basic, the animation does an amazing job of bringing the game world to life, and the audio (especially the natives jabbering) is superb. At times the game world can be quite breathtaking with a tremendous sense of scale. I'd definitely recommend Journey of the Gods to anyone owning a Quest at the moment. The game does truly do the headset justice.

My quest has some tracking problems within this game from time to time and quits the game for some seconds, this kills the immersion for me.
When you get into the pause menu within the game or if you start the game in a new session the character always looks into a direction no one needs to look, i then have to move by 90degrees to the right side to see what i want to see, this is for me a major problem within this game, especially if you dont have endless space in your room.

Graphics:
the graphics here are absolutely not made with a lot of love, compared to zelda. I mean other characters do not even look like humans as they are constructed with some triangles, squares and they dont even have a face. I really didnt feel like saving these people as they feel ridicolous.

Summed up: this is another techdemo for me. Story, graphics, design, bugs and othere issues that need to me worked on for a 30 dollar game. You made a good start here but i wont remember this game for very long.
